thread.title_full: Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon Tuesday approved the immediate

author: Ilan Lior
title: Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon Tuesday approved the immediate
text:
Finance Minister Moshe Kahlon Tuesday approved the immediate allocation of funds to temporarily extend the presence of security guards at preschools, schools and afternoon programs until 4 P.M.
The funding was approved for a two-week period, in response to the recent rise in terror attacks around the country.
The state will pay for the security guards in lower-income communities will be fully funded by the state, while wealthier communities will contribute 30 percent of the cost.
“I thank the finance minister who in these important hours presented for the approval of the inner cabinet significant additional funding for the security of our children in schools and kindergartens,” the chairman of the Union of Local Authorities, Modi’in Maccabim Re’ut Mayor Haim Bibas, said after the decision was announced
Bibas said the treasury’s contribution will help communities “to conduct normal life in time of emergency throughout the country.”
Herzliya Mayor Moshe Fadlon and Givatayim Mayor Ran Kunik ordered municipal employees in their respective cities to guard kindergartens.
Although they have no training and are not armed, the employees have been required to stand outside preschools when the children enter, wearing reflective vests, in order to deter potential attackers.
Kunik said the employees’ role was to “observe, survey and report.”
Kunik said that it was difficult if not impossible to hire security guards, but that the city would try to hire five additional guards for “preschools near building sites.”
Kunik said the city could not legally fund guards for private preschools and other programs. He proposed that parents pay for the additional security, “which is in fact already happening,” he said.
In Ramat Gan, city parking enforcers are patrolling near schools, municipal employees are temporarily joining the ranks of security guards and teachers will be joining crossing guards.
Ilan Lior
Haaretz Correspondent
